    <item>
      <title>RSF siege of El Fasher in Sudan has ‘hallmarks of genocide’, UN mission finds</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/19/rsf-siege-el-fasher-sudan-hallmarks-of-genocide-un-mission-north-darfur</link>
      <description><p>Report details harrowing 18-month occupation of North Darfur capital, showing destruction aimed at ethnic communities</p><p>The <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2025/oct/27/fears-civilians-sudan-paramilitary-rsf-capture-el-fasher">siege and capture</a> of the Sudanese city of El Fasher by the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces group last October bore “the hallmarks of genocide”, a UN-mandated fact-finding mission has said.</p><p>In a report detailing the harrowing 18-month occupation of the capital of North Darfur, investigators concluded that the RSF and allied militias deliberately inflicted conditions calculated to bring about the physical destruction of the Zaghawa and Fur ethnic communities.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/19/rsf-siege-el-fasher-sudan-hallmarks-of-genocide-un-mission-north-darfur">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>More than 1,000 Kenyans lured to fight for Russia in Ukraine war, report says</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/19/kenyan-soldiers-russia-ukraine-war-intelligence-report</link>
      <description><p>Intelligence findings read to parliament say ‘rogue’ agencies and individuals  recruiting Kenyan nationals to frontline</p><p>More than 1,000 Kenyans have been lured to fight for Russia in its war with Ukraine, according to an intelligence report to the Kenyan parliament that highlights the scale of a Russian operation taking African men to the frontline.</p><p>The majority leader of Kenya’s national assembly, Kimani Ichung’wah, said “rogue recruitment agencies and individuals in Kenya” were continuing to send Kenyan nationals to fight in the conflict, as he read MPs the summary of an investigation by Kenya’s National Intelligence Service.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/19/kenyan-soldiers-russia-ukraine-war-intelligence-report">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Countries that do not embrace AI could be left behind, says OpenAI’s George Osborne</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2026/feb/18/countries-do-not-embrace-ai-left-behind-george-osborne</link>
      <description><p>Without AI you will be a ‘weaker and poorer nation’, says former UK chancellor two months into job at US firm</p><p>The former chancellor George Osborne has said countries that do not embrace the kind of powerful AI systems made by his new employer, OpenAI, risk “Fomo” and could be left weaker and poorer.</p><p>Osborne, who is <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2025/dec/18/george-osborne-openai-big-tech-political-hires">two months into a job</a> as head of the $500bn San Francisco AI company’s “for countries” programme, told leaders gathered for the AI Impact summit in Delhi: “Don’t be left behind.” He said that without AI rollouts they could end up with a workforce “less willing to stay put” because they might want to seek AI-enabled fortunes elsewhere.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2026/feb/18/countries-do-not-embrace-ai-left-behind-george-osborne">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Kenyan authorities used Israeli tech to crack activist’s phone, report claims</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/17/trim-slugs-to-kenya-authorities-israel-tech-crack-activists-phone-report</link>
      <description><p>Citizen Lab report suggests Cellebrite software was used to break into Boniface Mwangi’s phone while he was under arrest</p><p>When Boniface Mwangi, the prominent Kenyan pro-democracy activist who plans to run <a href="https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/kenyan-rights-activist-plans-run-president-2027-2025-08-27/">for president in 2027</a>, had his phones returned to him by Kenyan authorities after his <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2025/jul/20/arrested-kenyan-activist-boniface-mwangi-faces-terror-charges">controversial arrest last July</a>, he immediately noticed a problem: one of the phones was no longer password protected and could be opened without one.</p><p>It was Mwangi’s personal phone, which he used to communicate with friends and mentors, and contained photos of private family moments with his wife and children. Knowing that its contents could be in the hands of the Kenyan government made Mwangi – who has described harassment and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2025/jun/29/activists-boniface-mwangi-agather-atuhaire-tanzania">even torture</a> – feel unsafe and “exposed”, he told the Guardian.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/17/trim-slugs-to-kenya-authorities-israel-tech-crack-activists-phone-report">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/news/audio/2026/feb/16/how-an-undercover-cop-foiled-an-is-plot-to-massacre-britains-jews-podcast</link>
      <description><p>The Guardian’s community affairs correspondent, <strong>Chris Osuh</strong>,<strong> </strong>reports on the plot by two IS terrorists to massacre Jews in Manchester, and how it was thwarted by an undercover sting</p><p>Walid Saadaoui had once worked as a holiday entertainer, organising dance shows and quizzes at a resort in his native Tunisia. After moving to the UK and marrying a British woman, he became a restaurateur and an avid keeper of birds.</p><p>All the while, however – as the Guardian’s community affairs correspondent, <strong>Chris Osuh</strong>, explains – he was hiding a secret: he had pledged allegiance to Islamic State.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/news/audio/2026/feb/16/how-an-undercover-cop-foiled-an-is-plot-to-massacre-britains-jews-podcast">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Floreana giant tortoise reintroduced to Galápagos island after almost 200 years</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/20/floreana-giant-tortoise-reintroduced-to-galapagos-island-after-almost-200-years</link>
      <description><p>Subspecies driven to extinction by hungry whalers returns after ‘back breeding’ programme using partial descendants</p><p>Giant tortoises, the life-giving engineers of remote small island ecosystems, are plodding over the Galápagos island of Floreana for the first time in more than 180 years.</p><p>The Floreana giant tortoise (<em>Chelonoidis niger niger</em>), a subspecies of the giant tortoise once found across the Galápagos, was driven to extinction in the 1840s by whalers who removed thousands from the volcanic island to provide a living larder during their hunting voyages.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/20/floreana-giant-tortoise-reintroduced-to-galapagos-island-after-almost-200-years">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Bolivia’s ex-leader Evo Morales reappears after months-long unexplained absence</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/20/bolivia-evo-morales-public-appearance</link>
      <description><p>Long-serving socialist former leader Evo Morales has reappeared in his political stronghold after almost seven weeks of unexplained absence</p><p>Bolivia’s long-serving socialist former leader, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/evo-morales">Evo Morales</a>, reappeared on Thursday in his political stronghold of the tropics after almost seven weeks of unexplained absence, endorsing candidates for upcoming regional elections and quieting rumours he had fled the country in the wake of the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/jan/03/explosions-reported-venezuela-caracas">US seizure of his ally</a>, Venezuela’s ex-president <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/nicolas-maduro">Nicolás Maduro</a>.</p><p>The weeks of hand-wringing over Morales’ fate showed how little the Andean country knows about what’s happening in the remote Chapare region, where the former president has spent the past year <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2025/may/08/bolivia-evo-morales">evading an arrest warrant</a> on human trafficking charges, and how vulnerable it is to fears about US president Donald Trump’s potential future foreign escapades.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/20/bolivia-evo-morales-public-appearance">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/bolivia">Bolivia</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/evo-morales">Evo Morales</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/americas">Americas</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump">Donald Trump</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/venezuela">Venezuela</category>
      <pubDate>Fri, 20 Feb 2026 04:10:29 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/20/bolivia-evo-morales-public-appearance</guid>

      <title>Leftist who defended child marriage elected as Peru’s interim president</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/19/jose-maria-balcazar-elected-peru-interim-president</link>
      <description><p>José María Balcázar, who argued for marriage at 14 and above, replaces José Jerí who was voted out after a scandal</p><p>Peru’s congress has elected José María Balcázar, an octogenarian leftist lawmaker who has defended child marriage, as the country’s interim president ahead of general elections in April.</p><p>Balcázar is Peru’s ninth president since 2016. The surprise election, in which Balcázar beat the favourite, María del Carmen Alva, a conservative, came after lawmakers <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/17/perus-president-ousted-in-express-impeachment-after-just-four-months">voted to remove José Jerí</a> as president on Tuesday after just four months in office, due to a scandal over <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/jan/22/peru-president-chinese-businessmen-secret-meeting">secretive meetings with Chinese businessmen</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/19/jose-maria-balcazar-elected-peru-interim-president">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Kimberly Prost and Luz del Carmen Ibáñez Carranza vow US reprisals will not affect work of international criminal court</p><p>When the Canadian Kimberly Prost learned Donald Trump’s administration had imposed sanctions on her, it came as a shock.</p><p>For years, she has sat as a judge at the international criminal court, weighing accusations of war crimes, genocide and crimes against humanity; now she is on the same list as terrorists and those involved in organised crime. “It really was a moment of a bit of disbelief,” she said.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/law/2026/feb/18/international-criminal-court-icc-judges-trump-sanctions">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>US says 11 people killed in latest strikes on alleged drug boats</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/17/us-military-boats-strikes</link>
      <description><p>Three boats targeted in eastern Pacific and Caribbean as Trump continues pursuit of alleged ‘narco-terrorists’</p><p>US military officials have said American forces launched assaults on three alleged drug-smuggling boats, killing 11 in one of the deadliest days of the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trump-administration">Trump administration’s</a> months-long campaign against alleged traffickers.</p><p>The military action on Monday brought the number of fatalities caused by US strikes to 145 since September, when <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump">Donald Trump</a> called on American armed forces to attack people deemed “narco-terrorists” on small vessels. There have been 42 known strikes in notorious drug-trafficking routes such as the Caribbean Sea and eastern Pacific Ocean, according to the Associated Press <a href="https://www.military.com/daily-news/2026/02/17/strikes-3-more-alleged-drug-boats-kill-11-people-us-military-says.html">reported</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/17/us-military-boats-strikes">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2026/feb/22/china-overtakes-us-as-germany-top-trading-partner</link>
      <description><p>Friedrich Merz to meet Xi Jinping in Beijing, with goods worth €251bn traded between two countries in 2025</p><p>China has overtaken the US as Germany’s top trading partner, figures have shown, as the chancellor, Friedrich Merz, prepares for his first visit to Beijing since taking office.</p><p>Merz will head to China on Tuesday and will be welcomed with military honours on Wednesday in Beijing by the prime minister, Li Qiang, before later meeting the president, Xi Jinping, for talks over dinner, his spokesperson Sebastian Hille said.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2026/feb/22/china-overtakes-us-as-germany-top-trading-partner">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Osaka stunned by anonymous gift of gold bars to fix ageing water pipes</title>

      <description><p>Mayor says Japanese city will respect donor’s specification that £2.7m gift must be used to repair dilapidated system</p><p>Osaka has received a hefty gift of gold bars worth 560m yen (£2.7m) from an anonymous donor and a request for its specific use: to fix the Japanese city’s dilapidated water pipes.</p><p>The gold bars, weighing a total of 21kg (46lb), were given to the Osaka City Waterworks Bureau in November by the donor who wants to help improve ageing water pipes, the mayor, Hideyuki Yokoyama, told reporters on Thursday.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/20/osaka-stunned-by-anonymous-gift-of-36m-in-gold-to-fix-ageing-water-pipes">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2026/feb/22/australia-will-examine-all-options-to-avoid-new-15-tariffs-announced-by-donald-trump</link>
      <description><p>The trade minister, Don Farrell, says Australia has ‘consistently advocated’ against the ‘unjustified tariffs’, after the US president announced new levies</p><ul><li><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/live/2026/feb/22/australia-news-live-tony-burke-home-affairs-syria-albanese-chalmers-productivity-commission-federal-police-labor-liberal-angus-taylor-coalition-ntwnfb">Follow our Australia news live blog for latest updates</a></p></li><li><p>Get our <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/email-newsletters?CMP=cvau_sfl">breaking news email</a>, <a href="https://app.adjust.com/w4u7jx3">free app</a> or <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/series/full-story?CMP=cvau_sfl">daily news podcast</a></p></li></ul><p>Australia will “examine all options” after the US president Donald Trump announced a <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/21/trump-tariffs-15-percent">temporary 15% tariff</a> would apply to US imports from all countries.</p><p>The US president’s move came less than 24 hours after the<a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/20/trump-supreme-court-tariffs-ruling"> US supreme court overturned</a> his original 10% import tariff. Shortly after the ruling, Trump announced he was reinstating the 10% duties using a different law before raising it again to 15%.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2026/feb/22/australia-will-examine-all-options-to-avoid-new-15-tariffs-announced-by-donald-trump">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>One woman is subject to temporary exclusion order over security concerns, but  home affairs minister says group is ‘not consistent’ in their beliefs</p><ul><li><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/live/2026/feb/22/australia-news-live-tony-burke-home-affairs-syria-albanese-chalmers-productivity-commission-federal-police-labor-liberal-angus-taylor-coalition-ntwnfb">Follow our Australia news live blog for latest updates</a></p></li><li><p>Get our <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/email-newsletters?CMP=cvau_sfl">breaking news email</a>, <a href="https://app.adjust.com/w4u7jx3">free app</a> or <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/series/full-story?CMP=cvau_sfl">daily news podcast</a></p></li></ul><p>Tony Burke says authorities “know the state of mind” of each of the 34 Australian women and children stuck in a Syrian detention camp, but says his options to prevent them returning to Australia are limited.</p><p>The home affairs minister, who represents a south-western Sydney electorate with a high Muslim population, also warned Pauline Hanson’s recent derogatory comments against Muslims in Australia could incite violence.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2026/feb/22/tony-burke-says-australia-has-few-options-to-block-return-of-34-women-and-children-from-syrian-camp-ntwnfb">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Nightly raids and violent beatings: Australia urged to accept citizens trapped in Syria as conditions in Roj camp deteriorate</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2026/feb/21/as-conditions-in-roj-camp-deteriorate-australia-urged-to-accept-citizens-trapped-in-syria</link>
      <description><p>Aid workers say the camp where 34 women and children are being held are ‘dire’ and present more risk than if they were repatriated</p><ul><li><p>Get our <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/email-newsletters?CMP=cvau_sfl">breaking news email</a>, <a href="https://app.adjust.com/w4u7jx3">free app</a> or <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/series/full-story?CMP=cvau_sfl">daily news podcast</a></p></li></ul><p>Conditions in the north-eastern Syrian camp where 34 Australians have been forcibly returned are deteriorating dramatically, with reports of near-nightly raids, and increasingly violent beatings, amid worsening uncertainty over their futures.</p><p>The 11 women and 23 Australian children <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2026/feb/17/tony-burke-australian-women-children-syria">forced back to Roj camp on Monday </a>returned to find their tents – formerly huddled collectively in a row known as Australia Street – demolished and their possessions seized.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2026/feb/21/as-conditions-in-roj-camp-deteriorate-australia-urged-to-accept-citizens-trapped-in-syria">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>UK in talks with US over ‘best possible deal’ for British firms amid higher tariffs threat</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/22/uk-in-talks-with-us-over-best-possible-deal-for-british-firms-amid-higher-tariffs-threat-trump</link>
      <description><p>Business leaders expect UK to ‘double down’ on deal announced by Donald Trump and Keir Starmer in 2025</p><ul><li><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2026/feb/22/trump-trade-war-risks-undermining-his-hopes-of-hefty-us-interest-rate-cuts-tariffs">Graeme Wearden: Trump’s trade war risks undermining his hopes of hefty US interest rate cuts</a></p></li></ul><p>High-level talks with the US administration over the threat of increased tariffs are under way as the UK government says it wants “the best possible deal” for UK companies.</p><p>Business leaders said they expected the UK to “double down” on the existing <a href="https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/us-uk-economic-prosperity-deal-epd">Economic Prosperity Deal (EPD)</a> – announced by Donald Trump and Keir Starmer in <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2025/may/08/trump-and-starmer-confirm-breakthrough-us-uk-trade-deal">May last year</a> – rather than walk away.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/22/uk-in-talks-with-us-over-best-possible-deal-for-british-firms-amid-higher-tariffs-threat-trump">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trump-tariffs">Trump tariffs</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/business/internationaltrade">International trade</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/business/business">Business</category>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump">Donald Trump</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/us-news">US news</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/business/tariffs">Tariffs</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/business/economics">Economics</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/world">World news</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/europe-news">Europe</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/eu">European Union</category>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/22/france-summons-us-ambassador-charles-kushner-comments-quentin-deranque</link>
      <description><p>Official US social media accounts posted about rise of ‘violent radical leftism’ after killing of Quentin Deranque in Lyon last week</p><p>The French foreign minister, Jean-Noël Barrot, has said he will summon Charles Kushner, the US ambassador to France, over comments related to the killing of the French far-right activist Quentin Deranque.</p><p>Deranque was beaten to death in Lyon last week during a fight with alleged hard-left activists.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/22/france-summons-us-ambassador-charles-kushner-comments-quentin-deranque">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Blackwater founder Erik Prince has joined the drone-warfare fray in Ukraine, SEC filings reveal</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/22/erik-prince-drone-company-ukraine</link>
      <description><p>Battle-tested Ukrainian startup that advertises a ‘Killbox’ drone recruited Prince as non-executive chair</p><p>After multiple sources previously <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2025/sep/07/erik-prince-blackwater-ukraine">told the Guardian</a> that Erik Prince – Maga ally and founder of the now defunct mercenary company <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/xe-blackwater">Blackwater</a> – was looking to work with <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/ukraine">Ukraine</a>’s invaluable drone sector, recent Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) documents <a href="https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/2092574/000110465926009198/tm2529424-6_s1.htm">confirm he now is</a>.</p><p>Swarmer, which bills itself as a battle-tested Ukrainian startup specializing in autonomous drone software, <a href="https://finance.yahoo.com/news/erik-prince-files-ipo-battle-221311353.html">filed for an initial public offering</a> and has recruited Prince to help sell the company as non-executive chair.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/22/erik-prince-drone-company-ukraine">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/22/greenland-does-not-need-us-hospital-boat-sent-by-trump-says-denmark</link>
      <description><p>Leaders of both Denmark and Arctic territory rebuff US president’s claim that  islanders are ‘not being taken care of’</p><p>Greenland has said it does not need medical assistance from other countries, after <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump">Donald Trump</a> said he was sending a hospital ship to the autonomous Danish territory he wants to acquire.</p><p>The US president said he would dispatch the vessel in a social media post on Saturday, claiming that Greenlanders were not getting the healthcare they needed.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/22/greenland-does-not-need-us-hospital-boat-sent-by-trump-says-denmark">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/22/saint-francis-of-assisi-skeleton-on-public-display-for-first-time</link>
      <description><p>Hundreds of thousands of visitors expected for month-long display of 13th-century saint’s remains</p><p>Saint Francis of Assisi’s skeleton is going on full public display from Sunday for the first time, in a move that is expected to draw hundreds of thousands of visitors.</p><p>Inside a nitrogen-filled case with the Latin inscription “Corpus Sancti Francisci” (the body of Saint Francis), the remains are being shown in the Italian hillside town’s Basilica of Saint Francis of Assisi.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/22/saint-francis-of-assisi-skeleton-on-public-display-for-first-time">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/22/mike-huckabee-israel-comments-condemned-arab-muslim-countries</link>
      <description><p>Arab and Islamic governments issue joint statement denouncing comments made on Tucker Carlson podcast</p><p>Governments from across the Islamic world have condemned remarks by the US ambassador to Israel, Mike Huckabee, suggesting it would “be fine” for Israel to claim a broad swath of the Middle East.</p><p>Huckabee, an evangelical Christian pastor and former Arkansas governor, has long been an outspoken supporter of Israeli settlements in occupied Palestinian territories. In an interview with the conservative US commentator Tucker Carlson published on Friday, the ambassador pointed to verses in the Bible that some Jews and evangelical Christians interpret as signifying the divine right of Jews to claim the land from the Nile to the Euphrates.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/22/mike-huckabee-israel-comments-condemned-arab-muslim-countries">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Iran willing to dilute uranium stockpile as fresh protests erupt</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/21/iran-refusing-to-export-highly-enriched-uranium-but-willing-to-dilute-purity</link>
      <description><p>Proposal will be at heart of offer to US as Trump considers whether to attack Iran</p><p>Iran is refusing to export its 300kg stockpile of highly enriched uranium, but is willing to dilute the purity of the stockpile it holds under the supervision of UN nuclear inspectorate the IAEA, Iranian sources have said.</p><p>The proposal will be at the heart of the offer Iran is due to make to the US in the next few days, as the US president, Donald Trump, weighs whether to use his vast naval buildup in the Middle East to attack the country.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/21/iran-refusing-to-export-highly-enriched-uranium-but-willing-to-dilute-purity">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Combative Carlson-Huckabee interview reveals US right’s chasm over Israel</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/21/tucker-carlson-mike-huckabee-israel</link>
      <description><p>Parts of Maga view Israel with suspicion, but US ambassador continues to believe in its divine right to much of the Middle East</p><p>Parts of the Maga right may be souring on Israel – but a hardline form of Christian Zionism seems to remain unofficial Trump administration policy, if a heated debate between Tucker Carlson and Mike Huckabee, the US ambassador to Israel, is any indication.</p><p>On Friday, Carlson released a confrontational video interview with Huckabee, conducted at Ben Gurion airport in Israel, that vividly illustrated a gaping divide between two factions of the Republican party. On one side is a Christian nationalist stream of the Maga movement, which views the United States’s close relationship with Israel with increasing suspicion. On the other is an older Christian conservative establishment that views that alliance as a totem of US foreign policy – and in some cases believes that Israeli Jews possess a <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/20/mike-huckabee-israel-middle-east-tucker-carlson">divine right</a> to a large swathe of the Middle East, US public opinion be damned.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/21/tucker-carlson-mike-huckabee-israel">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Iran prepares nuclear counterproposal as US considers limited military strikes</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/21/iran-nuclear-counterproposal-us-strikes-threat</link>
      <description><p>Trump orders massive buildup of naval forces in Middle East, leading to fears of an imminent war</p><p>Iran’s foreign minister has said he expects to have a draft counterproposal ready within days after nuclear talks with the US this week, while Donald Trump said he was considering limited military strikes.</p><p>The US president has <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/19/us-military-buildup-in-middle-east-intensifies-but-to-what-end">ordered a massive buildup of naval forces</a> in the Middle East, including repositioning aircraft carriers and other warships, leading to fears of an imminent war. But it is not clear if the military movements are intended as an intimidation tactic to put pressure on Iran to make concessions on its nuclear programme.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/21/iran-nuclear-counterproposal-us-strikes-threat">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2026/feb/18/delhi-ai-expo-modi-jostles-lead-south</link>
      <description><p>Google, Anthropic and OpenAI bosses to mingle with global south leaders wrestling for control over technology</p><p>Silicon Valley tech billionaires will land in Delhi this week for an AI summit hosted by India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, where leaders of the global south will wrestle for control over the fast-developing technology.</p><p>During the week-long AI Impact Summit, attended by thousands of tech executives, government officials and AI safety experts, tech companies valued at trillions of dollars will rub along with leaders of countries such as Kenya and Indonesia, where average wages dip well below $1,000 a month.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2026/feb/18/delhi-ai-expo-modi-jostles-lead-south">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/17/tarique-rahman-sworn-in-bangladesh-prime-minister</link>

      <title>‘I feel like a ghost’: new father deported by ICE to Bhutan that exiled his family</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/15/bhutanese-nepali-refugee-ice-trump-immigration</link>
      <description><p>Mohan Karki – one of many people ICE has deported to countries with which they have little connection – leaves behind his wife and seven-month-old baby he has yet to hold</p><p>Tika Basnet sat facing the glow of her iPhone, a red <em>tika</em> pressed into the center of her forehead. Seven-month-old Briana slept on her lap, her breathing soft and uneven. On the other side of the screen was Mohan Karki, Basnet’s husband, who had yet to hold his daughter.</p><p>For Karki, nearly 9,000 miles (14,500km) away, it was already morning. He was in hiding in south Asia, his exact location withheld for his safety, his face breaking into pixels as he watched his daughter sleep.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/15/bhutanese-nepali-refugee-ice-trump-immigration">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/13/bangladesh-election-bnp-wins</link>
      <description><p>Voting was largely peaceful in an election seen as a test of Bangladesh’s democracy after years of political turmoil </p><p>The Bangladesh Nationalist party, led by <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/12/tarique-rahman-bnp-bangladesh-election">Tarique Rahman</a>, has won a sweeping victory in the country’s first election since a gen Z uprising toppled the autocratic regime of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/sheikh-hasina">Sheikh Hasina</a>.</p><p>Results from the election commission confirmed the BNP alliance had won 212 seats, returning the party to power after 20 years, while the rival alliance, led by the Islamist party Jamaat-e-Islami, won 77 seats.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/feb/13/bangladesh-election-bnp-wins">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>European leaders said in December that Europe was ready to lead a “multinational force” in Ukraine as part of a peace agreement proposal</p><p>Searches are expected to continue today at Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor’s previous home – Royal Lodge, in Windsor – as calls grow for a probe into the former prince’s links with Jeffrey Epstein.</p><p><em>Lucy Hough speaks to the Guardian’s police and crime correspondent, Vikram Dodd, about what could be next for Andrew here:</em></p><p><em>If the government bring forward this bill with the support of the King then we will back it. We have to be realistic. Andrew is the eighth in line to the throne, so there’s no chance of him becoming our monarch.</em></p><p><em>And so parliament really should be focused on things that are of more importance to the public, whether that’s the economy, crime, the health service, immigration. But if the bill does come before parliament, then we’ll support it.</em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/live/2026/feb/22/uk-education-ehcp-attainment-schools-andrew-latest-news-updates">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <pubDate>Sun, 22 Feb 2026 15:37:41 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/live/2026/feb/22/uk-education-ehcp-attainment-schools-andrew-latest-news-updates</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/c791dff3d6077887ba440ce083ec391d7236d41f/1166_0_6827_5464/master/6827.jpg?width=140&quality=85&auto=format&fit=max&s=b9730e5a128507d846bb0d4d436403f1">

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2026/feb/22/mother-of-nottingham-attacks-victim-calls-for-whole-truth-to-emerge-at-inquiry</link>
      <description><p>Emma Webber, mother of Barnaby Webber, expects ‘shocking’ failures into care of triple killer Valdo Calacone to emerge at inquiry starting on Monday</p><p>The mother of a student who was killed in the 2023 Nottingham attacks has said she will “fight to the bitter end” to get to the truth of how Valdo Calocane was free to attack, before the beginning of a public inquiry into the incident.</p><p>Barnaby Webber and Grace O’Malley-Kumar, 19-year-old students, and 65-year-old caretaker Ian Coates were fatally stabbed by Calocane on 13 June 2023 in a frenzied attack. Early the next day, Calocane drove a van into pedestrians Wayne Birkett, Sharon Miller and Marcin Gawronski, leaving all three with severe and life-changing injuries.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2026/feb/22/mother-of-nottingham-attacks-victim-calls-for-whole-truth-to-emerge-at-inquiry">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2026/feb/22/tories-scrap-high-interest-student-loans-says-kemi-badenoch</link>
      <description><p>Education secretary Bridget Phillipson suggests priority is grants for poorer students rather than cutting interest</p><p>Kemi Badenoch has said the Conservatives would scrap the “unfair debt trap” of high interest rates on student loans, piling pressure on Labour ministers to tackle the growing outrage over the high costs.</p><p>The education secretary, Bridget Phillipson, admitted the system of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/money/2026/jan/23/student-loans-graduates-plan-2-interest-rates">plan 2 loans</a> had “problems” but suggested the government’s priority would be maintenance grants for poorer students, rather than tackling the high interest rates.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2026/feb/22/tories-scrap-high-interest-student-loans-says-kemi-badenoch">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Only 10% of boys aged 14-16 read daily for pleasure, National Literacy Trust finds</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/education/2026/feb/22/teenage-boys-reading-books-research</link>
      <description><p>Exclusive: Report says British teenagers’ time for books is being crowded out by schoolwork, screens and sports</p><p>Fewer than one in 10 boys aged 14 to 16 in the UK read daily, according to research, which found reading for pleasure was being crowded out of teenage lives by schoolwork, screens and sports.</p><p>While reading declines for both boys and girls in early adolescence, there are “signs of recovery” among girls in later teenage years, but boys’ engagement remains persistently low, according to the National Literacy Trust (NLT).</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/education/2026/feb/22/teenage-boys-reading-books-research">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2026/feb/22/met-police-ai-tools-officer-misconduct-palantir</link>
      <description><p>Exclusive: Police Federation condemns deployment of US firm’s tech to analyse behaviour as ‘automated suspicion’</p><p>Scotland Yard is using AI tools supplied by the US tech company Palantir to monitor staff behaviour in an attempt to root out failing officers, the Guardian has learned.</p><p>The Metropolitan police has previously declined to confirm or deny whether it used technology supplied by the company, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2026/feb/05/calls-to-halt-uk-palantir-contracts-grow-amid-lack-of-transparency-over-deals">which also works for the Israeli military and Donald Trump’s ICE operation</a>. It has now confirmed that it is using Palantir’s AI to analyse internal data about sickness levels, absences from duty and overtime patterns in an effort to identify potential shortcomings in professional standards.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2026/feb/22/met-police-ai-tools-officer-misconduct-palantir">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Worst of the worst? Most US immigrants targeted for deportation in 2025 had no criminal charges, documents reveal</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/22/us-immigration-trump-administration</link>
      <description><p>A Guardian analysis finds the vast majority of people who entered deportation proceedings for the first time from January to August last year had no criminal convictions</p><p>A Guardian analysis of government records has found that the vast majority – 77% – of people who entered deportation proceedings for the first time in 2025 had no criminal conviction, exposing a stark gap between the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trump-administration">Trump administration</a>’s rhetoric and reality.</p><p>Within days of Donald Trump’s inauguration, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) trotted out a phrase that his surrogates would come to use over and over again: “the worst of the worst.”</p><p>Fewer than half of the people in the data (40%) had any criminal charge against them, and only 23% had a conviction.</p><p>Of those who did have a criminal conviction, nearly half were for non-violent traffic and immigration offenses.</p><p>Traffic offenses alone made up nearly 30% of the convictions, the largest category by far.</p><p>Some 9% of criminal convictions were for assault, while only 1% were for sexual assault and just 0.5% were for homicide.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/22/us-immigration-trump-administration">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>‘One of the legends’: Bad Bunny joins tributes to US salsa pioneer Willie Colón</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/21/willie-colon-music-salsa-dead-aged-75</link>
      <description><p>Puerto Rican rapper speaks at concert of Colón’s influence after trombonist, vocalist and composer dies aged 75</p><p>Tributes have poured in from stars including <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/bad-bunny">Bad Bunny</a> for Willie Colón, the pioneering trombonist, vocalist and composer who died on Saturday aged 75.</p><p>With more than 30m albums sold, multiple platinum records and 11 combined Grammy and Latin Grammy nominations, Colón is among the most successful salsa artists of all time.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/21/willie-colon-music-salsa-dead-aged-75">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>All nine bodies of skiers killed in California avalanche recovered</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/21/california-avalanche-bodies-recovered</link>
      <description><p>Six additional skiers survived tragedy in Sierra Nevadas near Lake Tahoe, a popular winter sport destination</p><ul><li><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/21/california-avalanche-ski-trip">‘They were mothers, wives, friends’: how a ski trip turned deadly in the California mountains</a></p></li></ul><p>Officials announced on Saturday that the bodies of all nine missing skiers who were killed in a devastating avalanche in California had been recovered, following days of search efforts.</p><p>The avalanche happened in the Sierra Nevada mountains in northern California near Lake Tahoe, a popular skiing and winter sport destination. No more people are left missing after Tuesday’s deadly avalanche.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/21/california-avalanche-bodies-recovered">Continue reading...</a></description>
